It's time for House & Senate leadership to follow our example and get this done.

The situations my constituents are facing are serious, and they are immediate. We need to focus on supporting the programs that Americans are depending on right now, not worry about scoring short-term political points.

Every day, I hear the personal, heartbreaking stories of the dire health & financial challenges facing Central Virginians. This package isn't perfect, but #VA07 expects us to pursue common ground ‚Äî this package provides an opportunity for Congress to move forward and do its job.

- Direct aid to local governments facing budget shortfalls, so they don't have to layoff essential personnel like teachers, police, EMS or utility providers
 
- Funding to expand broadband access, an essential ingredient for telehealth, work-from-home, and virtual learning

- Unemployment assistance AND support for small businesses and nonprofits, so we're encouraging economic recovery from every angle 
 
- Funding for affordable childcare for working parents

Some key aspects of our plan to break the stalemate in Washington & deliver the next phase of real COVID-19 relief: 
 
- Funding for increased COVID-19 testing
 
- Second stimulus check for American families & individuals, with fixes to make sure people aren't left out this time

The plan we're proposing today is the result of weeks of work between 25 Democrats and 25 Republicans from all across the country. We've listened to the requests & feedback from #VA07 and beyond, and put together a 6 month framework to help get Americans get back on their feet.

Honored to witness history & attend today's signing ceremony at the @WhiteHouse. The agreement btw #Israel, #UAE, & #Bahrain will transform the #MiddleEast. Thank you @realDonaldTrump for this great accomplishment.
I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues in Congress to help promote the conditions for that lasting peace and security.

As Bahrain‚Äôs Foreign Minister Abdullatif al Zayani put it, "Today's agreement is an important first step and it is now incumbent upon us to work urgently and actively to bring about the lasting peace and security our people deserve."

As Prime Minister Netanyahu today said, "those who bare the wounds of war cherish the blessings of peace." Those blessings will only be fully realized with hard work and continued United States engagement.

Just as we did then, we should mark this day with President Trump hosting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the foreign ministers of UAE and Bahrain as hopefully a harbinger of more good things to come.
As well when President Clinton hosted Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and King Hussein of Jordan in 1994.

The significance of today‚Äôs steps for peace is not lost on those of us who have sought it across the decades. I vividly remember when President Carter hosted Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar Sadat to sign the first peace agreement with Egypt in 1979.
I pray that these accords will open the door to a new era of peace between Israel and her neighbors, including progress to a negotiated two state solution to the Israeli/Palestinian conflict.

Today, I was honored and humbled to personally witness the signing ceremony at the White House for the two historic peace agreements between the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Israel. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/15/us/politics/trump-israel-peace-emirates-bahrain.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

I also look forward to continuing to work with the Administration and my colleagues in Congress to promote future progress towards true and lasting peace, and bringing greater security to Israel, and all nations in the region.

Like with past agreements with Egypt and Jordan, the United States has always been a vital interlocutor, steadfast in our special alliance with Israel, including economic support and critical assurances of her qualitative military edge.

I pray that this momentum might ultimately forge a path to an agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, ensuring a secure, Jewish, democratic Israel living side-by-side with a Palestinian state with peace, security, and prosperity for both peoples.
Such an achievement would have been impossible without years of diligent work from Israel, the UAE, Bahrain, the State Department, and Presidential administrations going back generations.

Today's historic agreements to normalize relations between Israel and Bahrain and the UAE represent further movement toward better relations throughout the region and better security for Israel and her neighbors.
It will increase their linkages and opportunities, particularly in the face of growing Iranian aggression. I thank @realDonaldTrump and his administration for their leadership on this issue.

Q: Why don‚Äôt markets update quickly in response to aggregate demand shocks?
A: They have long-run expectations and write long-run contracts and expectations. Read our report to find out how they could benefit from monetary stability üëáüèΩ
Learn more about how monetary policy affects the state of social capital in America: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=051267FC-0147-4E31-BE80-946E0543AF82
Avoiding future costly downturns like the Great Recession should be a top priority of economic policy. A monetary system that yields stable nominal income growth would help achieve this priority.

Both financial and personal investment into the institutions of civil society decline. Some of these wounds heal with the labor market during recoveries. Others leave long-lasting‚Äîeven permanent‚Äîscars.
Layoffs disconnect people‚Äîoften already-marginalized people‚Äîfrom the labor force, depriving them of the social ties, emotional stability, and structure that come with working life.
Deep recessions are not only economic, but social disasters. Lost income makes it less affordable to start and maintain families.

Americans lost trillions of dollars of income and tens of millions of person-years of work. The job losses were also concentrated among disadvantaged groups, increasing inequality along the dimensions of both education and race. https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=051267FC-0147-4E31-BE80-946E0543AF82
